revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-09 23:45:23.000000000', 'message': "DVR: Restarting l3 agent loses centralized fip ip on qg-interface

When l3 agent is restarted on a dvr_snat node that is configured
for L3_HA and has a centralized FloatingIP configured to the
qg-interface in the snat_namespace, that FloatingIP is not
re-configured to the qg-interface when agent starts.

The reason being, the cidr is not being retrieved from the
keepalived instance and only retrieved from the
centralized_fip_cidr_set.

If 'L3_HA' is configured we need to retrieve it from the keepalived
instance.

This patch fixes the problem by retrieving the cidrs from the
keepalived instance for the qg-interface.

Change-Id: I848a20d06e2d344503a4cb1776dbe2617d91bc41
Closes-Bug: #1740450
(cherry picked from commit 64028a389ff904f15e471b44bd5b3979c5db2cd2)
"}]
commit_message:
DVR: Restarting l3 agent loses centralized fip ip on qg-interface

When l3 agent is restarted on a dvr_snat node that is configured
for L3_HA and has a centralized FloatingIP configured to the
qg-interface in the snat_namespace, that FloatingIP is not
re-configured to the qg-interface when agent starts.

The reason being, the cidr is not being retrieved from the
keepalived instance and only retrieved from the
centralized_fip_cidr_set.

If 'L3_HA' is configured we need to retrieve it from the keepalived
instance.

This patch fixes the problem by retrieving the cidrs from the
keepalived instance for the qg-interface.

Change-Id: I848a20d06e2d344503a4cb1776dbe2617d91bc41
Closes-Bug: #1740450
(cherry picked from commit 64028a389ff904f15e471b44bd5b3979c5db2cd2)

commit_message:
Gate: Fix version of ansible deployed via dev-deploy

This pins the version of ansible deployed via the makefile
dev-deploy directives to the version used in zuul.  This was
causing issues with docker, as make dev-deploy setup-host was
deploying ansible 2.6. Ansible 2.6 introduces a new flag to the
docker_container module (init) that is incompatible with our
current roles, which resulted in observed failures in osh-infra
and osh

Change-Id: Ibc885b53bce77eb36817024b21efb0e99865f690

commit_message:
Re-enable KVM

A recent kernel update in the nodepool images has resolved the issue
we were seeing with using KVM on some hosting providers.
This patch removes the exclusion for those hosting providers and
allows the Octavia gates to use KVM if it is available on the host.

Change-Id: I980cdbc67d6e7b3a8a2520b2279ff3a1cdf68c4b

commit_message:
Add support to regenerate port mac_address

Passing 'null' (None) as the mac address in a port update
request causes the port's mac address to be re-generated
using the base MAC address Neutron uses for VIFs.

This change implementes a temporary lib api definition
with a new converter that will generate valid mac if the
data provided is None.

APIImpact: Port mac_addr regenerated if None passed on update.
Closes-Bug: #1768690
Change-Id: I7d04beea4810718c3b745de8ea97897b1323267e

    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC

    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2018-06-27 21:25:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28162, 'date': '2018-06-27 21:27:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

there are secondary/stagged keys which will validate your token'}, {'account_id': 28162, 'date': '2018-06-27 21:27:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

to make it look good we may increase token expiration and rotation period up to 12 hours'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2018-06-27 21:29:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28162, 'date': '2018-06-27 21:34:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

ok, let's then increase token expiration to 12 hours, key rotation to 12 hours. @Tin, @Gage is that fine with you?"}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2018-06-27 21:38:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> ok, let's then increase token expiration to 12 hours, key rotation
 > to 12 hours. @Tin, @Gage is that fine with you?

12 is a better default imo, yes"}, {'account_id': 28162, 'date': '2018-06-27 21:46:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2018-06-27 21:51:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

12 hours is more reasonable!'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2018-06-27 22:21:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2018-06-27 22:26:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2018-06-27 22:27:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Workflow'}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2018-06-27 22:27:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2018-06-27 22:51:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2018-06-27 22:51:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2018-06-27 22:52:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26686, 'date': '2018-06-28 00:14:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

The token expiration and rotation frequency are driven by separate security questions; max active keys is determined by the other two.

The advantage of a shorter token expiration is that it limits the time an attacker can use a stolen token. Also, it reduces token revocation overhead, see https://github.com/openstack/keystone/commit/7494f93dc3d295d5aa3564c614107d0332467a80
so I'm not seeing here a reason we would deviate from upstream defaults.

Rotation frequency should be set based on how long it takes to perform a keyspace attack and derive the token encryption key (the reason we have to rotate Fernet tokens in the first place). Not having performed this analysis, I can only recommend erring on the side of caution with a more frequent rotation. If we are working off openstack defaults of expiration = 1 hour and max active keys = 3, then rotation frequency would be 1 hour. A more frequent rotation only becomes a problem if the tokens are being rotated faster than they can be generated, and/or become a non-trivial source of cpu loading, neither of which will be an issue at 1/hr.

There is no possibility of non-expired tokens being purged from the keyring when the formula is followed. The primary key is rotated out at 1 hour, and remains a secondary key for an additional hour, ensuring that even a token issued at the end of the primary key's life can still be validated up until the end of the secondary key's life."}, {'account_id': 28162, 'date': '2018-06-28 00:43:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 28162, 'date': '2018-06-28 00:44:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2018-06-28 01:52:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> (1 comment)

I think the idea is to determine the expiration time and a good rotation frequency and then increase the number of keys - and not pin the number of keys to 3, and then do algebra and adjust the rotation frequency.  In either case, there is likely performance impact else we can rotate every minute with expiration of 1 hr so long we have 62 keys.  

Do we not need to deal with credential keys as well since they are also fernet-base?'}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2018-06-28 02:06:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

I am okay with this as people who want to tune this can do so using appropriate override.  The documentation for the formula would help folks determine the correct number of keys once they determine the appropriate expiration time and rotation frequency.'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2018-06-29 03:22:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2018-06-29 07:20:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2018-06-29 09:31:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 21691, 'date': '2018-06-29 10:15:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

recheck'}, {'account_id': 28162, 'date': '2018-06-29 20:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2018-06-29 20:17:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow+1

recheck'}]

commit_message:
Update fernet keys rotation and expiration

Keystone token expiration, rotation frequency and active keys
values should follow the formula:

max_active_keys = (token_expiration / rotation_frequency) + 2

max_active_keys by default is 3
token expiration set to 43200 (12h)
rotation frequency set to 12 hours

Change-Id: Ia04daec9b2905ef2d3f2d4fbb43557dda220dc70
Signed-off-by: Ruslan Khanbikov <rk760n@att.com>

I think there is at least one issue w.r.t. the dependency between need_metadata_footer and need_multiphase - on master if you need multiphase then you get a MIMEPutter which by default gets you footers support and the mime boundary gets sent to the object server.

Here, there Putter interface allows multiphase to be required but not metadata footers, and the mime boundary may not be sent (I think, from inspection). Since we don't use a Putter that way maybe we should eliminate the possibility by making multiphase depend on metadata_footer? Alternatively, some more tests would be in order - if the unified class is meant to support other combinations then we should be sure they work.

I confess to being a little confused by the various places where content-length, transfer-encoding, and setting the Expect header is handled - but it doesn't look quite the same as on master. I'd love it if it could be further simplified or at least gathered into one place."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-10-31 23:54:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

This lets us have one object that knows about the various wacky things
we do on object PUT. Callers only need to answer two questions:

(1) will you send metadata after the object body?

(2) will you create a .durable file?

Change-Id: Ic4bcaae654e3a9fa4487a468d8a8cfb9c4171a9a

commit_message:
Unify Putter and MIMEPutter into a single class.

This lets us have one object that knows about the various wacky things
we do on object PUT. Callers only need to answer two questions:

(1) will you send metadata after the object body?

(2) will you create a .durable file?

This simplifies the object controllers' PUT paths and may, in the
future, ease the replacement of the MIME-based PUT protocol with
something less weird (once someone invents it).

Change-Id: Ic4bcaae654e3a9fa4487a468d8a8cfb9c4171a9a

commit_message:
Remove unclear wording in parameters

This was brought up in a previous change[0], but these parameters
are worded to detail that they each contain varius attributes. This
works when listing them in the yaml file, but the meaning is lost
when these parameters are rendered into tables and becomes slightly
confusing.

This change removes the various wording of "contains the following"
from the various object parameters.

[0] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/569741/3

Change-Id: Ibced08ba0c2e5f8cbadbacc675dc0cf6b745ecdc

'}, {'created': '2018-02-20 13:30:07.000000000', 'message': 'New dict format of allocations (v1.11, v1.12)

v1.11:
Microversion 1.11 does not need any support in osc so we just skip over
that in this patch.

v1.12:
* Dict format to PUT /allocations.
  Compare for versions 1.11 and 1.12:
  $ openstack \
      --debug \
      --os-placement-api-version VERSION \
      resource provider allocation set CONSUMER-ID \
        --project-id PROJECT-ID \
        --user-id USER-ID \
        --allocation rp=RP-ID,MEMORY_MB=1
* Fields added to the GET /allocations response: project_id, user_id.
  $ openstack \
      --debug \
      --os-placement-api-version VERSION \
      resource provider allocation show CONSUMER-ID
* Dict format in allocation_requests of GET /allocation_candidates.
  $ openstack \
      --debug \
      --os-placement-api-version VERSION \
      allocation candidate show \
        --resource VCPU=1,MEMORY_MB=1

Partially-Implements: blueprint placement-osc-plugin-rocky
Change-Id: Ie2f6a9e73e9b00968c8e850aea705ffccdfa124b

commit_message:
New dict format of allocations (v1.11, v1.12)

v1.11:
Microversion 1.11 does not need any support in osc so we just skip over
that in this patch.

v1.12:
* Dict format to PUT /allocations.
  Compare for versions 1.11 and 1.12:
  $ openstack \
      --debug \
      --os-placement-api-version VERSION \
      resource provider allocation set CONSUMER-ID \
        --project-id PROJECT-ID \
        --user-id USER-ID \
        --allocation rp=RP-ID,MEMORY_MB=1
* Fields added to the GET /allocations response: project_id, user_id.
  $ openstack \
      --debug \
      --os-placement-api-version VERSION \
      resource provider allocation show CONSUMER-ID
* Dict format in allocation_requests of GET /allocation_candidates.
  $ openstack \
      --debug \
      --os-placement-api-version VERSION \
      allocation candidate show \
        --resource VCPU=1,MEMORY_MB=1

Partially-Implements: blueprint placement-osc-plugin-rocky
Change-Id: Ie2f6a9e73e9b00968c8e850aea705ffccdfa124b

stack@rocky:~/osc-placement$ openstack allocation candidate list --resource VCPU=1 --resource MEMORY_MB=1024 --resource DISK_GB=20
Operation or argument is not supported with version 1.0
stack@rocky:~/osc-placement$ export OS_PLACEMENT_API_VERSION=1.10
stack@rocky:~/osc-placement$ openstack allocation candidate list --resource VCPU=1 --resource MEMORY_MB=1024 --resource DISK_GB=20
+---+----------------------------------+--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------------+
| # | allocation                       | resource provider                    | current inventory used/capacity            |
+---+----------------------------------+--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------------+
| 1 | VCPU=1,MEMORY_MB=1024,DISK_GB=20 | 66bcaca9-9263-45b1-a569-ea708ff7a968 | VCPU=0/128,MEMORY_MB=0/11205,DISK_GB=0/193 |
+---+----------------------------------+--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------------+

commit_message:
CLI allocation candidates (v1.10)

Adds the "openstack allocation candidate list" command.

Change-Id: I5508243771e20a9ab7724731a4289b218594dee5
Partially-Implements: blueprint placement-osc-plugin-rocky

commit_message:
Usages per project and user (v1.8, v1.9)

Adds support to "openstack resource provider allocation set"
for microversion 1.8 where --project-id and --user-id are
required (and highly recommended).

Adds a new "openstack resource usage show" command
for microversion 1.9 and GET /usages.

Change-Id: I8ec19c8138611a06b41ec3ad949f45b8f6d7ec17
Partially-Implements: blueprint placement-osc-plugin-rocky

commit_message:
Make vexxhost specific pool for kata flavors

The kata test instances can only run in vexxhost currently and there are
delays in processing these node requests because we content with the
openstack requests as well. Split this into a separate pool so that we
can better model resource quotas/maxes as well as creating a separate
thread just for these node requests.

Change-Id: I449bba31c0e4a29d20af6ca7f3888bf9dc85945c

commit_message:
Discover the gid of the docker group for mistral

The gid of the docker group is discovered by stating the gid of the
file /var/run/docker.sock. The gid of the docker group is not fixed,
so it must match the gid assigned when docker is installed on the
host. If no docker.sock exists, the custom fact will return nil.

This change also makes sure the user and group ensure_resource calls are
tagged so that docker-puppet.py can include those tags explicitly.

Blueprint: container-prepare-workflow

Change-Id: I94fa558480e408f76e69d292b1d84849ddf9a2a2

commit_message:
Get providers directly from ORM to make startup take half as long

In a time of starting neutron with more than 100 loadbalancers this
reduces real from 37.819s to 13.978s.

Change-Id: I8659869220073fe73bb7d8624ea43d0c7f28d41d
(cherry picked from commit bea49e63d78df57ef29a0304919b93a054c186b6)

Get providers directly from ORM to make startup take half as long

In a time of starting neutron with more than 100 loadbalancers this
reduces real from 37.819s to 13.978s.

commit_message:
Add recover_deployment workflow

If a deployment was created before the introduction of config-download,
this workflow can recover this deployment, and transform it into one
that works with config-download.

Change-Id: I83e7329c1e0e7457ab221bc9b92357aed7275548
Implements: blueprint config-download-workflows

commit_message:
Move database creation into role (tacker)

There is no record for why we implement the database creation outside
of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we remove the group_vars which were duplicated from the
role, and remove the DB setup tasks as they are no longer required.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/578862
Change-Id: I671a9d40554f820d0ec085083227fa0e29e4141a

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-22 22:48:03.000000000', 'message': "py3: port tempurl

Changed some header-cleaning methods in tempurl to not modify the
dictionary that they're iterating over since you can't do that in py3.

Refactored the tests a little to use some signature-generating helper
methods instead of duplicating the same HMAC construction over and
over again. I wouldn't have bothered, but that duplicated HMAC
construction didn't work on py3 since HMAC keys and messages have to
be bytes.

Change-Id: Icca61001eb55d51d7b07faa13a273ca802783d6f
"}]
commit_message:
py3: port tempurl

Changed some header-cleaning methods in tempurl to not modify the
dictionary that they're iterating over since you can't do that in py3.

Refactored the tests a little to use some signature-generating helper
methods instead of duplicating the same HMAC construction over and
over again. I wouldn't have bothered, but that duplicated HMAC
construction didn't work on py3 since HMAC keys and messages have to
be bytes.

Change-Id: Icca61001eb55d51d7b07faa13a273ca802783d6f

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-28 16:07:25.000000000', 'message': "Move database creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the database creation outside
of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement a new variable called 'watcher_db_setup_host'
which is used in the role to allow delegation of the database setup
task to any host, but defaults to the first member of the galera_all
host group. We also document the variable 'watcher_galera_address' which
has been used for a long time, but never documented. A bunch of unused
variables have also been removed.

Change-Id: I3b845ee913e3abc70bbc59b85142ebd55b92de51

commit_message:
Move database creation into role

There is no record for why we implement the database creation outside
of the role in the playbook, when we could do it inside the role.

Implementing it inside the role allows us to reduce the quantity of
group_vars duplicated from the role, and allows us to better document
the required variables in the role. The delegation can still be done
as it is done in the playbook too.

In this patch we implement a new variable called 'watcher_db_setup_host'
which is used in the role to allow delegation of the database setup
task to any host, but defaults to the first member of the galera_all
host group. We also document the variable 'watcher_galera_address' which
has been used for a long time, but never documented. A bunch of unused
variables have also been removed.

Change-Id: I3b845ee913e3abc70bbc59b85142ebd55b92de51

commit_message:
Add support to select ceph version

We are closing in on adding Ceph Mimic support and
want to ensure we can select either Luminous or Mimic
for running our tests.

For example Ubuntu 18.04 must run Ceph Mimic because
Luminous is not available (yet), Debian doesn't have
Ceph Mimic packages so we must run Luminous there.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/576247/
Change-Id: If84ecbf86f3ebde8e69a1a26759ad967d061725a

commit_message:
Mark unit test test_get_objects_queries_constant as unstable

This test is failing a lot in our check and gate queues.
It's reported in [1].
To make life easier, this test will be marked as unstable
until [1] will be fixed.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1775220

Change-Id: Ie37e72b98f0d8e6e3ccafb1fe38a57bd50777331
Related-Bug: #1775220

commit_message:
Align parsed() call with cmd2 versions >= 0.7.3

In version 0.7.3, cmd2 moved the parsed method from class Cmd()
to class ParserManager().

Change-Id: Ie0c057ffaeaa05c4f5e0f3599aab850245c55066
Closes-Bug: #1751822

commit_message:
Add example host confd file for barbican

Missing example file could confuse user to implement this role.
Since the host is not 'barbican' like named.

commit_message:
Align parsed() call with cmd2 versions >= 0.7.3

In version 0.7.3, cmd2 moved the parsed method from class Cmd()
to class ParserManager().

Change-Id: Ie0c057ffaeaa05c4f5e0f3599aab850245c55066
Closes-Bug: #1751822

[{'created': '2017-12-15 09:37:39.000000000', 'message': 'Verify the Swift container exists with a small utility workflow

The previous method of `swift.head_container` worked well, but it caused
Mistral to log the exception raised by swiftclient. This then left a red
flag in the logs that confused users debugging.

This new method checks for the container by listing all the containers
in the account and checking for the name.

Closes-Bug: #1730712
Change-Id: I4a6b5b9b31a4f76840a6c6070a1d733ceade5c64

'}, {'created': '2018-04-11 12:39:42.000000000', 'message': "Verify the Swift container exists with a small utility workflow

The previous method of `swift.head_container` worked well, but it caused
Mistral to log the exception raised by swiftclient. This then left a red
flag in the logs that confused users debugging.

This new method checks for the container by listing all the containers
in the account and checking for the name. We only consider containers
that start with the full name we are looking for - Swift doesn't have an
exact match, only a prefix filter.

The workflow then can be used to create the container, capturing the
logic that was duplicated in each individual workflow.

Closes-Bug: #1730712
Depends-On: I41649d15c57e16bffcf7870a52bc01177aae7cc8
Change-Id: I4a6b5b9b31a4f76840a6c6070a1d733ceade5c64

commit_message:
Verify the Swift container exists with a small utility workflow

The previous method of `swift.head_container` worked well, but it caused
Mistral to log the exception raised by swiftclient. This then left a red
flag in the logs that confused users debugging.

This new method checks for the container by listing all the containers
in the account and checking for the name. We only consider containers
that start with the full name we are looking for - Swift doesn't have an
exact match, only a prefix filter.

The workflow then can be used to create the container, capturing the
logic that was duplicated in each individual workflow.

Closes-Bug: #1730712
Depends-On: I41649d15c57e16bffcf7870a52bc01177aae7cc8
Change-Id: I4a6b5b9b31a4f76840a6c6070a1d733ceade5c64

commit_message:
Use openstack CLI for ironic

After ironicclint to 2.4.0 we have an interfaces incompatibility,
with the old call: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'cafile'

Closes-Bug: 1778847

Change-Id: I64d0df91f37b6baa5df1833e438a7eb1c06852cd

commit_message:
Remove "-oooq" from toci script name

The symlink that resolved this is no longer in the repo. We only
have a single toci runner script now.

Related-Bug: #1778974
Change-Id: I2fc830c9452766719ec482f2b4ee1a97e7123b29

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-05-11 09:03:43.000000000', 'message': "Default environment/services/* to docker

This updates the relevant environment/services templates so that
they also default to docker. Without this change users of these
services could end up with mismatched (unsupported) deployments.

Additionally, this picks environment/services-docker as the
source of truth when resolving collisions for moving those over

commit_message:
Default environment/services/* to docker

This updates the relevant environment/services templates so that
they also default to docker. Without this change users of these
services could end up with mismatched (unsupported) deployments.

Additionally, this picks environment/services-docker as the
source of truth when resolving collisions for moving those over
environment/services. So environment/services now contain all of
the containerized services' env files used to be located in
environment/services-docker. The latter will be deleted later to
prevent future desync of contents.

Co-authored-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I923731f46ea26582160a11d2dfe85792ab74110b
(cherry picked from commit e691bbe026455cd64cfbef83db420559cde00bba)

[{'created': '2018-06-29 06:41:43.000000000', 'message': "tasks: lxc_apparmor: Fix links for disabled profiles

The /etc/apparmor.d/local/* files are for user overrides. Symlinking
these to disable does not disable the profile since the main one still
lives in /etc/apparmor.d/. Moreover, the symlink destination for the
'ping' profile was wrong so we fix the typo to use a unique name for
that profile.

Change-Id: Iba8095f1068bc6f00064dd31b92cea5931a33b90
"}]
commit_message:
tasks: lxc_apparmor: Fix links for disabled profiles

The /etc/apparmor.d/local/* files are for user overrides. Symlinking
these to disable does not disable the profile since the main one still
lives in /etc/apparmor.d/. Moreover, the symlink destination for the
'ping' profile was wrong so we fix the typo to use a unique name for
that profile.

Change-Id: Iba8095f1068bc6f00064dd31b92cea5931a33b90

Please add test for this bug. Thanks'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2018-06-12 17:58:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

This may cleanup the bad access rule but if I understand the bug correctly we should get a fix that doesn't allow the rule with cidr 'lala' for a share with NFS access to get inserted into the database in the first place.  From the bug cited, an access type not supported error is returned to the user when User adds rule2 user 'lala' but an IP type access rule is created then with cidr 'lala'.  If this is correct then that is the fundamental issue that needs to be addressed in this bug fix."}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2018-06-20 06:02:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Circling back to this, seems like the appropriate fix, I was wrapped up on "error" rules never being presented to the driver in the "access_list" object.. but they will certainly be presented in the "delete_rules" to perform any cruft cleanup as per the original design. I'm sorry about the confusion.. 

I like Zhongjun's idea for a tempest test around this scenario, haobing, would you like to contribute one to manila-tempest-plugin? 

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 16643, 'date': '2018-06-20 06:03:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Cannot remove user rule for NFS share

Use generic driver create share, then add user type access failed.
We can not use 'manila access-deny' to delete the user rule
in a NFS share db.
This path fix this issue.

Change-Id: I9375c4be9361d593102a382eb9c14c2d776bb1aa
Closes-Bug:#1591357

commit_message:
NetApp cDOT driver skip vserver route with no gateway

Skip route creation if user decided to configure neutron network
without a gateway.

Closes-Bug: #1777126
Change-Id: Ic54e3aa7fc8327464110fff40d02c690d8b19122

commit_message:
Limit formatting routes when adding resources

By default, routes.mapper.Mapper.resource adds a bunch of formatted
routes that accept anything after a '.'. Our spec says only .xml
and .json are accepted so limit the formatting to those valuse.

This allows identifiers with a '.' in urls. A few tests were added
to the extensions test to prove that .xml and .json are stripped
but other values are not.

It is already modified in cinder [1].

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1307956

Change-Id: I91d8aa967446b5d7ce52f1b245149304494777f3
Closes-bug: #1774353

commit_message:
Add glance auth information to ironic.conf for communication

This adds the necessary config for ironic to communicate with
glance for image storage and retrieval.

Change-Id: Iec5d83715d0dcd83e61bb369f42353efac97e6d0

commit_message:
Switch to using stestr

According to Openstack summit session [1] stestr is
maintained project to which all Openstack projects should migrate.

Let's switch it then.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-python-pti

Change-Id: I7b48f945c0c1b14c916229658fd34949aa76fe69
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chucks@redhat.com>

commit_message:
use versioned keystone endpoint in OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_URL

Horizon uses OPENSTACK_KEYSTONE_URL to generate browser redirects for
web sso (in openstack_auth/utils.py). In order to generate valid URLs,
this value must use a versioned keystone endpoint.

Change-Id: Ifd8b7dea83a4566b69f76898952f908395c590a4

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-26 23:32:59.000000000', 'message': "Always run mysql init bundle

This init container runs docker-puppet manually and is responsible of
provisioning the mysql users and passwords. This currently doesn't get
ran every time since the configuration stays the same, even if the users
or passwords change (which are gotten from hieradata). Allowing this to
run every time will allow us to change database passwords

Closes-Bug: #1762991
Change-Id: I1f07272499b419079466cf9f395fb04a082099bd
(cherry picked from commit 6c40b1586ab1269e124f0f71d094834137819375)
"}]
commit_message:
Always run mysql init bundle

This init container runs docker-puppet manually and is responsible of
provisioning the mysql users and passwords. This currently doesn't get
ran every time since the configuration stays the same, even if the users
or passwords change (which are gotten from hieradata). Allowing this to
run every time will allow us to change database passwords

Closes-Bug: #1762991
Change-Id: I1f07272499b419079466cf9f395fb04a082099bd
(cherry picked from commit 6c40b1586ab1269e124f0f71d094834137819375)

[{'created': '2018-06-26 20:52:30.000000000', 'message': "Fix quota error when deleting temporary volume

When deleting a volume, always use the admin context to fetch the
admin_metadata that indicates whether it's a temporary volume.

This fixes a bug where a non-admin user failed to retrieve the
admin_metadata, which caused the volume to not be treated as temporary.
This, in turn, caused quota usage to be incorrectly updated.

Closes-Bug: #1778774
Change-Id: I8e6b0c726dc6498b28795a1ea0520ef05e53f047

commit_message:
Fix quota error when deleting temporary volume

When deleting a volume, always use the admin context to fetch the
admin_metadata that indicates whether it's a temporary volume.

This fixes a bug where a non-admin user failed to retrieve the
admin_metadata, which caused the volume to not be treated as temporary.
This, in turn, caused quota usage to be incorrectly updated.

Closes-Bug: #1778774
Change-Id: I8e6b0c726dc6498b28795a1ea0520ef05e53f047

[{'created': '2018-06-29 18:53:10.000000000', 'message': "Rename keystone.tests.unit.token

It seems that some debugging utilities have issues trying to import
`token` with our test module being called 'token'. This change makes
it so that the debuggers work (notably pycharm is one of these).

It is good in general to support easy debugging of tests/service.

Change-Id: Icdd84f8308bba21c5f8f3a98a4a0ae18bb67b641
"}]
commit_message:
Rename keystone.tests.unit.token

It seems that some debugging utilities have issues trying to import
`token` with our test module being called 'token'. This change makes
it so that the debuggers work (notably pycharm is one of these).

It is good in general to support easy debugging of tests/service.

Change-Id: Icdd84f8308bba21c5f8f3a98a4a0ae18bb67b641

[{'account_id': 28456, 'date': '2018-06-12 18:28:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-06-12 18:29:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2018-06-20 14:02:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-07 03:08:42.000000000', 'message': 'Start MySQL on localhost for galera_secure_node

When running MySQL on bare metal, it starts up the secure script
before configuring anything which means that it listens on all
interfaces by default.

In scenarios where the load balancer might be colocated with the
database server, it would cause a conflict and it would refuse
to start up (even if the database server is already configured
not to listen on that interface, the configuration only gets
dropped later in the play).

This sets the environment configuration to start it up on localhost
only and then resets it once it is done.  It should not affect
existing deployment but help with bare metal ones.

Change-Id: I883e32678ea3cc2eea09d23db5eecfce35aee6f2
'}]
commit_message:
Start MySQL on localhost for galera_secure_node

When running MySQL on bare metal, it starts up the secure script
before configuring anything which means that it listens on all
interfaces by default.

In scenarios where the load balancer might be colocated with the
database server, it would cause a conflict and it would refuse
to start up (even if the database server is already configured
not to listen on that interface, the configuration only gets
dropped later in the play).

This sets the environment configuration to start it up on localhost
only and then resets it once it is done.  It should not affect
existing deployment but help with bare metal ones.

Change-Id: I883e32678ea3cc2eea09d23db5eecfce35aee6f2

commit_message:
Switch non-voting jobs to use Zuul stanza

The extra jobs that we have are not something that is needed, we simply can
set the jobs to non-voting in the project definition and avoid having non
voting jobs.

Change-Id: If7e15b57302a9ff80dc8ae0824ce850468b85985

commit_message:
Expire mysql binary logs out of the box

As reported in the bug, these can grow to 10s to 100s of GB
in a month. To reduce the chance of filling the disk and
bringing down the control plane this change defines
an expiry time.

Closes-Bug: 1720113
Change-Id: I508aad1f515d5108a3d08c90318b70d0a918908c

commit_message:
Adding api_version to FakeApp

In order to use app.api_version['<some_service>'] we need to have the
api_version on FakeApp otherwise the test will fail.

Patch that will benefit from this:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/572536/

Change-Id: Ibb3c548daf2a62b6c4aefb5e257372dd5c56521e

That should be fixed now.

commit_message:
Merge server create schema for config drive extension

As nova extensions has been deprecated already and goal is to
merge all scattered code into main controller side.
Currently schema and request/response extended code are there
among all extensions.

This commit merge the schema part of create server for config extensions.

Partially implements: blueprint api-extensions-merge-rocky

Change-Id: I0bdb82c1692c547be6edc9729b2fd3e415b35646

commit_message:
Merge server create schema for BDM v2 extension

As nova extensions has been deprecated already and goal is to
merge all scattered code into main controller side.
Currently schema and request/response extended code are there
among all extensions.

This commit merge the schema part of create server for BDM v2 extensions.

Partially implements: blueprint api-extensions-merge-rocky

Change-Id: I49146f5b2e7635aa500054e9506e9bf28f6a2ce5

commit_message:
Fix sphinx-docs job for stable branch

build-openstack-sphinx-docs jobs fail on stable branches due to the new
pip version 10 introduces some previously Warning as Error: in case of
calling "pip install" without any package name, the command fails.
tox_install.sh is called during docs job without any package passed to
pip.

On master and stable/queens tox_install.sh is not used anymore, this is
why stable/pike is the first version to be fixed.

Change-Id: I8155fb720c35086ed3719fd282b8944627129f14
(cherry picked from commit a2be3ca4c974d3a0f9c3ec74f1543c1e50fb52f5)

commit_message:
Fix sphinx-docs job for stable branch

build-openstack-sphinx-docs jobs fail on stable branches due to the new
pip version 10 introduces some previously Warning as Error: in case of
calling "pip install" without any package name, the command fails.
tox_install.sh is called during docs job without any package passed to
pip.

On master and stable/queens tox_install.sh is not used anymore, this is
why stable/pike is the first version to be fixed.

Change-Id: Ic714e919542bd64194ba0d73910508d335719b68
(cherry picked from commit c75a6832bb5099a802e9920767f11f3c0fea652a)

throws this exception.

commit_message:
DB Migration: fix downgrade in 579c267fbb4d

The downgrade incorrectly modifies deleted
share access rules.

Also add a missing unit test for this migration.

Co-Authored-By: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>
Change-Id: If3700e7a18cbd8ae496b8c503c95cf6723485679
Closes-Bug: #1717392

subject: Replace support matrix ext with common library

This change depends on a change that failed to merge.'}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2017-12-18 15:49:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

Waiting for initial commit of library to be approved by oslo core.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-01-16 22:00:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

- Does doc/source/support_matrix.rst need to go as well?  That seems like something that should live in sphinx-feature-classification.
- It makes me leery that support-matrix.ini should have to change at all.  I would have expected the first iteration of this effort to entail *just* moving the infrastructure out.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-01-16 22:07:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> It makes me leery that support-matrix.ini should have to change at all. I would have expected the first iteration of this effort to entail *just* moving the infrastructure out.

Forget I said this.  I think I get that there's been drift in the various projects' implementations of the support matrix over time, which is where the discrepancies are coming from.  And this is the perfect time to squash all those discrepancies, when the cutover can be done cleanly, rather than having to worry about lockstepping with the sphinx-feature-classification lib later on.

Other concerns are still relevant, though."}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2018-01-24 21:20:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 170, 'date': '2018-01-24 21:20:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)

some inline comments. Maybe some more words in the commit message would help understand what's going on here.

Also, the changes here don't seem to be in sync with the changes proposed to nova, and they need to be. Probably just did this one first, but I'll err on the side of caution and mention it anyway. Thanks!"}, {'account_id': 10608, 'date': '2018-01-24 22:26:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Replace support matrix ext with common library

The code to generate a support matrix has been pulled into a common
library. Using this instead of duplicating code in various projects that
need it.

Change-Id: If01e440225fec2206e934ae7b0c6c2dce1266eab
Co-Authored-By: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7414, 'date': '2018-06-28 14:04:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

That makes sense, the documentation is very unclear as to the order of execution with include_playbook but I can see now that the handlers wouldn't get run until the parent playbook finishes.  I'll give your patch a try and push up another patch set."}, {'account_id': 7414, 'date': '2018-06-29 15:01:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 7414, 'date': '2018-06-29 15:12:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 7414, 'date': '2018-06-29 15:19:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

I rewrote this to remove the handler because it does not run in time.  The changes I've made in patch set 8 does a few things:

1) If the VM is in a shut down state the destroy command will fail, so I pull a status of the VMs and if any are shut down then the destroy command will skip and that VM will just get the start command.  If a VM is started but not responding it will be destroyed and then started.

2) We wait for connection and 2nd time in the rescue block to see if the VM is up and running

3) We do a final check on the VM status and hard fail if the vm is not running or it failed the 2nd connectivity check.  The reason we have to hard fail is because a rescue block sets the result of the play to success (it will still print out the errors but ansible will see the play as succeeding)

My testing is to run deploy-vms.yml and once a vm is started I issue a virsh destroy $vm, this causes the VM to fail the connectivity check.  If I want to test a rescue failure I then stop it again once the rescue task has started it.  This play now works in both scenarios."}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2018-06-29 16:35:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2018-06-29 16:35:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-26 17:52:36.000000000', 'message': 'Improve multi-node AIO robustness

In order to improve the readability and robustness of the mnaio feature
I have replaced the shell out to virsh tasks to use the virt module
where available.  I have also created a vm-status play that will
hopefully help resolve SSH failures into the VMs.  This play utilizes
the block/rescue/handler pattern to attempt to restart the VM once if
it fails the initial SSH check.  Hopefully this will reduce the SSH
failures due to a suck VM.  This adds a new variable called
vm_ssh_timeout which allows the deployer an easy place to override the
default timeout.  The python-lxml package is needed for the virt module.

Change-Id: I027556b71a8c26d08a56b4ffa56b2eeaf1cbabe9

commit_message:
Improve multi-node AIO robustness

In order to improve the readability and robustness of the mnaio feature
I have replaced the shell out to virsh tasks to use the virt module
where available.  I have also created a vm-status play that will
hopefully help resolve SSH failures into the VMs.  This play utilizes
the block/rescue/handler pattern to attempt to restart the VM once if
it fails the initial SSH check.  Hopefully this will reduce the SSH
failures due to a suck VM.  This adds a new variable called
vm_ssh_timeout which allows the deployer an easy place to override the
default timeout.  The python-lxml package is needed for the virt module.

Change-Id: I027556b71a8c26d08a56b4ffa56b2eeaf1cbabe9

commit_message:
Add doc build job locally

We want to control the doc build locally, so we do not depend on changes
to project-config.

Also, since this is a greenfield thing, use python3 from the start.

Change-Id: I811d492fe4aa5525003820936e16d7be4632209c

[{'created': '2018-06-26 20:33:13.000000000', 'message': 'kolla-build: Wrap tpl_dict.keys() in a list()

In python 3, tpl_dict.keys() returns a dict_keys object that does not
support indexing and is then indexed.
Wrap tpl_dict.keys() in a list() so it can be be indexed in python 2 and
3.

Closes-Bug: 1778781
'}]
commit_message:
kolla-build: Wrap tpl_dict.keys() in a list()

In python 3, tpl_dict.keys() returns a dict_keys object that does not
support indexing and is then indexed.
Wrap tpl_dict.keys() in a list() so it can be be indexed in python 2 and
3.

Change-Id: I17e3bbfc4eeba58e4bdd7fdd1ecdb21baa5c4461
Closes-Bug: 1778781

subject: Replace 'raise StopIteration' with 'return'
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-29 13:35:59.000000000', 'message': "Replace 'raise StopIteration' with 'return'

With PEP 479, the behaviour of StopIteration is changing. Raising it to
stop a generator is considered incorrect and from Python 3.7 this will
cause a RuntimeError. The PEP recommends using the return statement.

More details: https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0479/#examples-of-breakage

Change-Id: I5ea49c24c90d33e7fb5ae916c43e01d3d7537477
"}]
commit_message:
Replace 'raise StopIteration' with 'return'

With PEP 479, the behaviour of StopIteration is changing. Raising it to
stop a generator is considered incorrect and from Python 3.7 this will
cause a RuntimeError. The PEP recommends using the return statement.

More details: https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0479/#examples-of-breakage

Change-Id: I5ea49c24c90d33e7fb5ae916c43e01d3d7537477

messages: [{'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2018-06-18 20:15:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-06-29 13:20:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-06-29 15:21:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nlove for us to make this a provider eventually, but soonâ¢'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2018-06-29 15:21:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-18 20:15:33.000000000', 'message': 'Fix lspool issues on Mimic

With the Mimic release they have changed
the output of the "ceph osd lspools" command.

The old output (from Luminous):
$ceph osd lspools
5 glance,6 gnocchi,13 cinder,25 nova,

The new output (from Mimic):
$ceph osd lspools
1 glance
2 nova
3 cinder
4 gnocchi

This changes the usage of "ceph osd lspools"
to "ceph osd pool ls" which exists in both
versions and has the same output.

Example output of "ceph osd pool ls"
$ceph osd pool ls
glance
nova
cinder
gnocchi

We combine this with a grep with word-regexp
which will make sure we do a fullmatch on the
name of the pools.

Change-Id: I8883c8400ffc18672479fe2ad8cc7955a52bc466
'}]
commit_message:
Fix lspool issues on Mimic

With the Mimic release they have changed
the output of the "ceph osd lspools" command.

The old output (from Luminous):
$ceph osd lspools
5 glance,6 gnocchi,13 cinder,25 nova,

The new output (from Mimic):
$ceph osd lspools
1 glance
2 nova
3 cinder
4 gnocchi

This changes the usage of "ceph osd lspools"
to "ceph osd pool ls" which exists in both
versions and has the same output.

Example output of "ceph osd pool ls"
$ceph osd pool ls
glance
nova
cinder
gnocchi

We combine this with a grep with word-regexp
which will make sure we do a fullmatch on the
name of the pools.

Change-Id: I8883c8400ffc18672479fe2ad8cc7955a52bc466

commit_message:
Remove unused DB API instance_group_delete method

Since Ifbd53b13fa0fef62e0329283b73d587f367e46c2 we no
longer have compat code in the InstanceGroup object
and everything is handled in the API database, so we can
drop the legacy DB API methods for instance groups.

This is part of a series of cleanup changes.

Change-Id: I569ee5d582ce42d84afe2b4b6e702657abe8733b

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-26 14:18:59.000000000', 'message': 'Fix CLI docs for nova-manage api_db commands

There were a few changes needed here:

1. There is no "API cell database", just the API
   database, so this removes mentions of cells.

2. The VERSION argument was missing from the sync help.

3. The sync command does not create a database, it upgrades
   the schema. Wording for that was borrowed from the
   nova-manage db sync help.

4. Starting in Rocky, the api_db sync command also upgrades
   the schema for the optional placement database if configured
   so that's mentioned here as well.

Change-Id: Ibc49f93b8bd51d9a050acde5ef3dc8aad91321ca
Closes-Bug: #1778733
'}]
commit_message:
Fix CLI docs for nova-manage api_db commands

There were a few changes needed here:

1. There is no "API cell database", just the API
   database, so this removes mentions of cells.

2. The VERSION argument was missing from the sync help.

3. The sync command does not create a database, it upgrades
   the schema. Wording for that was borrowed from the
   nova-manage db sync help.

4. Starting in Rocky, the api_db sync command also upgrades
   the schema for the optional placement database if configured
   so that's mentioned here as well.

Change-Id: Ibc49f93b8bd51d9a050acde5ef3dc8aad91321ca
Closes-Bug: #1778733

commit_message:
Revert "Change build path from tmp to opt and disable COW"

This reverts commit 51fb5bb898be75d97ff5312e80e0bf381a29c810.

It didn't make any difference to the issue it was trying to solve,
so we should revert it because it changes the path of the builds
from before without adding any more value.

Change-Id: Id235766741398c54868c8b053d181c90e06f70db

commit_message:
RT stats deepcopy 1x/node instead of 1x/instance

As part of the update_available_resource periodic, the resource tracker
invokes deepcopy to copy stats into the compute node object.  But it was
doing this once for every instance, resulting in a substantial
performance hit.  This change moves the deepcopy out so it's done once
per compute node instead.

Change-Id: I49ab6e6a69175327c1a451bae911828a0a7573b1
Closes-Bug: #1777422

commit_message:
[placement] Extract create_allocation_list

The data assembly in set_allocations which results in an
AllocationList will be useful for forthcoming /reshaper code, so
here we extract it to its own public module-level method.

As noted in the associated TODO, there's some refactoring that can
be done to get methods like this in a better place while keeping the
handlers concise. util.py is getting too big and too diverse, so
there is not ideal.

Change-Id: I4b69ddaa6dbb66f977c5dad2d508cac3192d19d4

commit_message:
Devstack install fail if docker cgroup driver is systemd

The default value of cgroup-driver for kubelet is cgroupfs.
But the new version docker's cgroup value is systemd.
It needs the cgroup-driver parameter for kubelet to
ensure a successful installation.

Change-Id: I03a4289b8bc6d63c33085fa3ddd99341cb2de388
Closes-Bug: #1776591

commit_message:
Provide knob to disable ata secure erase

We need to allow the operator to able to
explicitly disable secure erase, in case
it is problematic in their environment
or hardware.

Change-Id: I4c68efa65cdd7f88f54f8dd9a8bcbeee9e8124a8
Story: #2002546
Task: #22108

commit_message:
Remove *.txt file content from py_pkgs lookup output

Some roles may have requirements.txt files. These are
not files we want to take into account when compiling
requirements for the repo build, so we remove them.

This has specifically become an issue due to ceph-ansible
carrying conflicting requirements to OpenStack's.

Change-Id: I0fd29dc4dcb008689f36d947bc971643dab8feec
(cherry picked from commit 054e50403640bc1321ef27e60b106a3ec5136622)

Remove *.txt file content from py_pkgs lookup output

Some roles may have requirements.txt files. These are
not files we want to take into account when compiling
requirements for the repo build, so we remove them.

This has specifically become an issue due to ceph-ansible
carrying conflicting requirements to OpenStack's.

Change-Id: I0fd29dc4dcb008689f36d947bc971643dab8feec
(cherry picked from commit 054e50403640bc1321ef27e60b106a3ec5136622)

commit_message:
Switch to stestr

According to Openstack summit session [1] stestr is
maintained project to which all Openstack projects
should migrate.
Let's switch it then.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-python-pti

Change-Id: Ia4c71631e4c51ec814bcefc115d4f5690c11e37b

commit_message:
Add py36 testenv

Python 3.6 is installed by default in Ubuntu 18.04 LTS.
Therefore, according to Transition Plan [1],
it'll be handy to have py36 testenv.

For more details, please check Python2 Deprecation Timeline [2]
and Python3-first Goal - Completion Criteria [3].

[1] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Python/Python36Transition
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20180529-python2-deprecation-timeline.html
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/575933/8/goals/stein/python3-first.rst@42

Change-Id: I4839bb3c9905a540e3ed61a36cacbf9a5f665b1b

subject: Optionally use oslo.log for deprecated opt logging
messages:
[{'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-04-10 17:32:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-04-10 17:44:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

It's worth noting that this actually changes the format of the log message slightly, specifically that it adds a "Deprecated: " prefix to the message.  That could cause issues for log parsing.  It actually breaks the unit tests if oslo.log is installed, although that would be easily fixed by relaxing the log message checks.

I think the benefit of re-enabling the fatal-deprecations functionality is worth that minor risk, but maybe it's worth a message to openstack-operators?'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-04-10 18:20:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This change may cause a warning message to turn into a fatal error that prevents a service from starting because report_deprecated_feature() throws an optional DeprecatedConfig exception. Is that what we want to do?'}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-04-10 19:53:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> This change may cause a warning message to turn into a fatal error
 > that prevents a service from starting because report_deprecated_feature()
 > throws an optional DeprecatedConfig exception. Is that what we want
 > to do?

Yeah, enabling that feature was actually the reason I did this.  Matt was asking about it in IRC this morning.  I thought we used to be able to do fatal-deprecations on config opts, but I can't find any evidence of it.  Apparently we didn't even have logging until https://github.com/openstack/oslo.config/commit/dc1d2340d552796ad66165bc0ff88e10fe0b6f06"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-04-10 20:21:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

OK. We should add some tests for this behavior. That might be easier if the import is done at the top of the file and the missing module is replaced with None, since it would then be possible to mock that variable out in the test code."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2018-04-10 20:37:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

commit_message:
Optionally use oslo.log for deprecated opt logging

While we can't add a hard dependency on oslo.log because it uses
oslo.config, in most cases oslo.log will be installed anyway.  In
the interest of being able to make use of features like
fatal_deprecations in oslo.log, let's use it if it's available.

Change-Id: If9499aa6fc28a6b92447b3825d3ca1957cb2255a

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-10 18:01:24.000000000', 'message': "normalize_name helper

Names of traits in placement are restricted to certain characters and
lengths.  Consumers (e.g. Nova virt driver implementations of
update_provider_tree) may wish to generate such names dynamically based
on inputs that don't necessarily know or follow those rules.  Such
consumers could use a convenient way to sanitize generated names such
that they conform to what placement expects.

This change set introduces a normalize_name method into the base
os_traits namespace.  It is identical to ResourceClass.normalize_name:
it converts non-alphanumeric characters to underscores, upcases, and
prepends CUSTOM_.

Change-Id: I0d83cb39abb417b337a3429d374e88942561d254
Related-Blueprint: update-provider-tree

Change-Id: I0d83cb39abb417b337a3429d374e88942561d254
Related-Blueprint: update-provider-tree

commit_message:
normalize_name helper

Names of traits in placement are restricted to certain characters and
lengths.  Consumers (e.g. Nova virt driver implementations of
update_provider_tree) may wish to generate such names dynamically based
on inputs that don't necessarily know or follow those rules.  Such
consumers could use a convenient way to sanitize generated names such
that they conform to what placement expects.

This change set introduces a normalize_name method into the base
os_traits namespace.  It is functionally identical to
ResourceClass.normalize_name: it converts and squashes any sequences of
non-alphanumeric characters to an underscore, upcases, and prepends
CUSTOM_.

Change-Id: I0d83cb39abb417b337a3429d374e88942561d254
Related-Blueprint: update-provider-tree

[{'created': '2018-06-26 10:19:44.000000000', 'message': 'mock utils.execute() in qemu-img unit test

There was a unit test that was not mocking utils.execute() and relying
on qemu-img being installed on the machine running the tests. This fixes
the test to mock out utils.execute() and raise a ProcessExecutionError
that simulates the expected behaviour from qemu-img.

Fixes bug: #1765122

Change-Id: Ia6fc089fce0cc0ba1fb8d4d4ffbf7f47968a0507

'}]
commit_message:
mock utils.execute() in qemu-img unit test

There was a unit test that was not mocking utils.execute() and relying
on qemu-img being installed on the machine running the tests. This fixes
the test to mock out utils.execute() and raise a ProcessExecutionError
that simulates the expected behaviour from qemu-img.

Fixes bug: #1765122

Change-Id: Ia6fc089fce0cc0ba1fb8d4d4ffbf7f47968a0507
(cherry picked from commit 815b11f70a3fd31888fb3e3e7b38e3a697bf6244)
(cherry picked from commit cf927f177be3ff0d1df069bc66f889ebcce93754)

commit_message:
Move multinode and centos jobs to check pipeline

This commit moves these jobs to the check pipeline as non-voting. We'll
start marking them as voting once they've proved to be stable enough.

Change-Id: I399ef54e8f855990b12d1b159ef58500d2169a96

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2018-06-27 11:08:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 26: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2018-06-27 16:35:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 26: Code-Review-1

There is still a lot of supervisord related stuff in packaging which would be nice to remove to reduce confusion:

```
doug@xps15:~/git/monasca-agent$ grep -ri supervisor
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:PATH=$PATH:/usr/local/bin # supervisord might live here
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:SUPERVISOR_PIDFILE="/var/tmp/monasca-agent-supervisord.pid"
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:SUPERVISOR_FILE="{config_dir}/supervisor.conf"
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:SUPERVISOR_SOCK="/var/tmp/monasca-agent-supervisor.sock"
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:SUPERVISORD="{prefix}/bin/supervisord"
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:SUPERVISORCTL="{prefix}/bin/supervisorctl"
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:    # If the socket exists, we can use supervisorctl
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:    if [ -e $SUPERVISOR_SOCK ]; then
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:        # If we're using supervisor, check the number of processes
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:        # supervisor is currently controlling, and make sure that it's the
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:        # same as the number of programs specified in the supervisor config
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:        supervisor_processes=$($SUPERVISORCTL -c $SUPERVISOR_FILE status)
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:        supervisor_processes=$(echo "$supervisor_processes" |
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:        supervisor_config_programs=$(grep -v pup $SUPERVISOR_FILE |
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:        if [ "$supervisor_processes" -ne "$supervisor_config_programs" ]; then
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:            echo "$supervisor_processes"
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:            echo "$DESC (supervisor) is NOT running all child processes"
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:            echo "$DESC (supervisor) is running all child processes"
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:        echo "$DESC (supervisor) is not running"
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:        echo "Starting $DESC (using supervisord)" "$NAME"
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:        $SUPERVISORD -c $SUPERVISOR_FILE -u $AGENTUSER --pidfile $SUPERVISOR_PIDFILE
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:        if [ -e $SUPERVISOR_PIDFILE ]; then
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:            kill `cat $SUPERVISOR_PIDFILE`
packaging/monasca-agent.init.template:            echo "Pid file $SUPERVISOR_PIDFILE not found, nothing to stop"
packaging/monasca-agent/source/supervisord.conf:[supervisord]
packaging/monasca-agent/source/supervisord.conf:logfile = supervisord/logs/supervisord.log
packaging/monasca-agent/source/supervisord.conf:identifier = supervisor
packaging/monasca-agent/source/supervisord.conf:pidfile = supervisord/supervisord.pid
packaging/monasca-agent/source/supervisord.conf:directory= supervisord
packaging/monasca-agent/source/supervisord.conf:[rpcinterface:supervisor]
packaging/monasca-agent/source/supervisord.conf:supervisor.rpcinterface_factory = supervisor.rpcinterface:make_main_rpcinterface
packaging/monasca-agent/source/supervisord.conf:file = supervisord/agent-supervisor.sock
packaging/monasca-agent/source/supervisord.conf:[supervisorctl]
packaging/monasca-agent/source/supervisord.conf:serverurl = unix://supervisord/agent-supervisor.sock
packaging/monasca-agent/source/supervisord.conf:stdout_logfile=supervisord/logs/collector.log
packaging/monasca-agent/source/supervisord.conf:stdout_logfile=supervisord/logs/forwarder.log
packaging/monasca-agent/source/supervisord.conf:stdout_logfile=supervisord/logs/dogstatsd.log
packaging/monasca-agent/source/supervisord.conf:stdout_logfile=supervisord/logs/pup.log
packaging/monasca-agent/source/setup_agent.sh:# set up supervisor
packaging/monasca-agent/source/setup_agent.sh:printf "Setting up supervisor....." | tee -a $logfile
packaging/monasca-agent/source/setup_agent.sh:mkdir -p $dd_base/supervisord/logs >> $logfile 2>&1
packaging/monasca-agent/source/setup_agent.sh:$dd_base/venv/bin/pip install supervisor==3.0b2 >> $logfile 2>&1
packaging/monasca-agent/source/setup_agent.sh:cp $dd_base/agent/packaging/datadog-agent/source/supervisord.conf $dd_base/supervisord/supervisord.conf >> $logfile 2>&1
packaging/monasca-agent/source/setup_agent.sh:ln -s $dd_base/supervisord/logs $dd_base/logs/supervisord >> $logfile 2>&1
packaging/monasca-agent/source/setup_agent.sh:    supervisord -c $dd_base/supervisord/supervisord.conf >> $logfile 2>&1 &
packaging/monasca-agent/source/setup_agent.sh:    # Checking that supervisord was properly launched
packaging/monasca-agent/source/setup_agent.sh:    supervisor_running=$?
packaging/monasca-agent/source/setup_agent.sh:    if [ $supervisor_running != 0 ]; then
packaging/monasca-agent/source/setup_agent.sh:      unknown_error "Failure when launching supervisor.\n"
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:SUPERVISOR_NOT_RUNNING="Supervisor is not running"
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:SUPERVISOR_CONF_FILE='supervisord/supervisord.conf'
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:SOCK_FILE='supervisord/agent-supervisor.sock'
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:supervisor_running() {
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:    # Returns true if the supervisor is running, and false if not.
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:    # We check if the supervisor is running by checking if
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:execute_if_supervisor_running() {
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:    # Executes `supervisord -c $SUPERVISOR_CONF_FILE $*`
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:    # if the supervisor is running.
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:    if supervisor_running; then
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:        supervisorctl -c $SUPERVISOR_CONF_FILE "$*"
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:        echo $SUPERVISOR_NOT_RUNNING
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:    # First, we check if supervisor is running:
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:    if ! supervisor_running; then
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:        echo $SUPERVISOR_NOT_RUNNING
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:        # Next, we check if supervisor is running all the datadog processes:
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:        # Check the number of datadog processes supervisor is
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:        # supervisor config file:
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:        status_output=$(supervisorctl -c $SUPERVISOR_CONF_FILE status)
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:        datadog_supervisor_processes=$(echo "$status_output" |
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:        supervisor_config_programs=$(grep -v pup $SUPERVISOR_CONF_FILE |
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:        if [ "$datadog_supervisor_processes" -ne "$supervisor_config_programs" ]; then
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:            echo "Supervisor is NOT running all child processes"
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:            echo "Supervisor is running all child processes"
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:        if supervisor_running; then
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:            echo "Supervisor is already running"
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:            echo "Starting supervisor"
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:            supervisord -c $SUPERVISOR_CONF_FILE
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:        execute_if_supervisor_running stop all
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:        # FIXME: This command won't do anything if the supervisor isn't running.
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:        # rely on the supervisor running. Once we stop starting the Agent in the
packaging/monasca-agent/source/agent:        execute_if_supervisor_running restart all
packaging/monasca-agent/smartos/dd-agent:		cd $dd_base && $dd_base/venv/bin/supervisord -n -c $dd_base/supervisord/supervisord.conf
packaging/monasca-agent/smartos/dd-agent:		cd $dd_base && $dd_base/venv/bin/supervisorctl  -c $dd_base/supervisord/supervisord.conf shutdown
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/supervisor.conf:[supervisorctl]
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/supervisor.conf:serverurl = unix:///var/tmp/monasca-agent-supervisor.sock
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/supervisor.conf:file=/var/tmp/monasca-agent-supervisor.sock
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/supervisor.conf:[rpcinterface:supervisor]
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/supervisor.conf:supervisor.rpcinterface_factory = supervisor.rpcinterface:make_main_rpcinterface
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/supervisor.conf:[supervisord]
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/supervisor.conf:logfile = /var/log/monasca/agent/supervisord.log
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/supervisor.conf:pidfile = /var/run/monasca-agent-supervisord.pid
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:SUPERVISOR_PIDFILE="/var/run/monasca-agent-supervisord.pid"
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:SUPERVISOR_FILE="/etc/monasca/agent/supervisor.conf"
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:SUPERVISOR_SOCK="/var/tmp/monasca-agent-supervisor.sock"
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:SUPERVISORD=$(which supervisord)
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:    # If the socket exists, we can use supervisorctl
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:    if [ -e $SUPERVISOR_SOCK ]; then
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:        # If we're using supervisor, check the number of processes
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:        # supervisor is currently controlling, and make sure that it's the
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:        # same as the number of programs specified in the supervisor config
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:        supervisor_processes=$(supervisorctl -c $SUPERVISOR_FILE status)
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:        supervisor_processes=$(echo "$supervisor_processes" |
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:        supervisor_config_programs=$(grep -v pup $SUPERVISOR_FILE |
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:        if [ "$supervisor_processes" -ne "$supervisor_config_programs" ]; then
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:            echo "$supervisor_processes"
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:            echo "$DESC (supervisor) is NOT running all child processes"
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:            echo "$DESC (supervisor) is running all child processes"
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:        echo "$DESC (supervisor) is not running"
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:        log_daemon_msg "Starting $DESC (using supervisord)" "$NAME"
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:        start-stop-daemon --start --quiet --oknodo --exec $SUPERVISORD -- -c $SUPERVISOR_FILE --pidfile $SUPERVISOR_PIDFILE
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:        log_daemon_msg "Stopping $DESC (stopping supervisord)" "$NAME"
packaging/monasca-agent-deb/monasca-agent.init:        start-stop-daemon --stop --retry 30 --quiet --oknodo --pidfile $SUPERVISOR_PIDFILE
packaging/Makefile:# Make the monasca agent debian package that includes supervisor, the forwarder
```'}, {'account_id': 16222, 'date': '2018-06-28 07:54:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 26:

Doug, I think we should not handle packaging in this change.

Thanks for pointing to this though. It hasn't been maintained for a longer time but I see some value in having universal packaging tooling. Let's discuss it separately and decide how to proceed."}, {'account_id': 26141, 'date': '2018-06-28 09:06:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 26:

I agree with Witek'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2018-06-28 09:43:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 26: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

commit_message:
Removed dependency on supervisor

To support python3 in the near future this was done:

* Removed dependency on supervisor.
* Added template configuration for systemd target that includes all
  services.
* Added templates configuration for systemd service for every single
  service.
* Changed monasca_setup to use the new templates.

In the meanwhile code was formated to cope with pep8 settings and some
other small changes were done to comply with pycodestyle and
pydocstring.

Task: 4126
Story: 2000975

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/566475/

Change-Id: I0d0c4ea41a830581d6b9f247fad6a2dda1f96cbe

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-25 20:16:32.000000000', 'message': 'Use instance project/user when creating RequestSpec during resize reschedule

When rescheduling from a failed cold migrate / resize, the compute
service does not pass the request spec back to conductor so we
create one based on the in-scope variables.

This introduces a problem for some scheduler filters like the
AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation filter since it will create the
RequestSpec using the project and user information from the current
context, which for a cold migrate is the admin and might not be
the owner of the instance (which could be in some other project).
So the AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation filter might reject the
request or select a host that fits an aggregate for the admin but
not the end user.

This fixes the problem by using the instance project/user information
when constructing the RequestSpec which will take priority over
the context in RequestSpec.from_components().

Long-term we need the compute service to pass the request spec back
to the conductor during a reschedule, but we do this first since we
can backport it.

NOTE(mriedem): RequestSpec.user_id was added in Rocky in commit
6e49019fae80586c4bbb8a7281600cf6140c176a so we have to remove its
usage in this backport.

Change-Id: Iaaf7f68d6874fd5d6e737e7d2bc589ea4a048fee
Closes-Bug: #1774205
(cherry picked from commit 8c216608194c89d281e8d2b66abd1e50e2405b01)
'}]
commit_message:
Use instance project/user when creating RequestSpec during resize reschedule

When rescheduling from a failed cold migrate / resize, the compute
service does not pass the request spec back to conductor so we
create one based on the in-scope variables.

This introduces a problem for some scheduler filters like the
AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation filter since it will create the
RequestSpec using the project and user information from the current
context, which for a cold migrate is the admin and might not be
the owner of the instance (which could be in some other project).
So the AggregateMultiTenancyIsolation filter might reject the
request or select a host that fits an aggregate for the admin but
not the end user.

This fixes the problem by using the instance project/user information
when constructing the RequestSpec which will take priority over
the context in RequestSpec.from_components().

Long-term we need the compute service to pass the request spec back
to the conductor during a reschedule, but we do this first since we
can backport it.

NOTE(mriedem): RequestSpec.user_id was added in Rocky in commit
6e49019fae80586c4bbb8a7281600cf6140c176a so we have to remove its
usage in this backport.

Change-Id: Iaaf7f68d6874fd5d6e737e7d2bc589ea4a048fee
Closes-Bug: #1774205
(cherry picked from commit 8c216608194c89d281e8d2b66abd1e50e2405b01)

commit_message:
Add py36 testenv

Python 3.6 is installed by default in Ubuntu 18.04 LTS.
Therefore, according to Transition Plan [1],
it'll be handy to have py36 testenv.

For more details, please check Python2 Deprecation Timeline [2]
and Python3-first Goal - Completion Criteria [3].

[1] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Python/Python36Transition
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20180529-python2-deprecation-timeline.html
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/575933/8/goals/stein/python3-first.rst@42

Change-Id: Ie537f11a4c2fe38a2fcec6d8a29a66c185101d6b

I have taken the liberty to add a releasenote, please check whether you agree with the wording, also amended the commit message a bit.

As for generating one yourself, the command I used is:

tox -e venv reno new bug-1742453

where the last parameter is a short description of the patch, in this case where it is a bug fix, just using the bug id should be fine. You will then get a template that you can modify accordingly.

See also https://docs.openstack.org/reno/latest/user/usage.html#creating-new-release-notes in addition to the link mentioned earlier.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-03-21 14:50:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Display private flavors in server list

Update the code so that "openstack server list --all"
also displays the names of private flavors.

Change-Id: I4804fcd905eaf67b1ad9b461084eaf0caa820d2f
Closes-Bug: #1742453

trying the containers multinode job instead of fs016 to see if the only issue is the loopback device for ceph'}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-06-27 09:56:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

the loop device is created in tripleo-ci/scripts/bootstrap-minimal.sh. We skipped it here http://logs.openstack.org/79/576879/20/check/tripleo-ci-centos-7-scenario001-multinode-oooq-container/d8fd2d1/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-06-26_15_41_12_020793. For some reason, it could not find the tripleo.sh script'}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-06-27 09:58:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

The tripleo-ci script should be run locally in the subnode but repo is not copied into the subnodes, we are probably skipping that part.'}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-06-27 10:08:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 22.'}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-06-27 10:09:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

John Trowbridge wrote:

> trying the containers multinode job instead of fs016 to see if the
> only issue is the loopback device for ceph

you changed the name of the job, but not the reference in the project layout, so nothing ran. Rerunning with other modifications, using again fs16'}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-06-27 10:30:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 23.'}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-06-27 10:56:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 24.'}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-06-27 11:32:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 25.'}, {'account_id': 10022, 'date': '2018-06-29 13:51:16.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

commit_message:
Add option to override confirmation in yaml-nic-config-2-script.py

This change adds the option to override the user input confirmation
to overwrite the nic template file. This is required when the script
is used inside automated jobs.

Closes-bug: 1770296

Change-Id: Ic8275bb3a944e503c73ab06c3d5140ea3563c0a6

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-29 13:47:34.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Port Group Add command when a port group already exists

When trying to create a Port Group that already exists and
may_exist=True, we still to insert it into DB resulting into
a failure. This patch fixes it.

Change-Id: I8b58750fa598e8d9a836114ecfecf11c7e84afd1
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix Port Group Add command when a port group already exists

When trying to create a Port Group that already exists and
may_exist=True, we still to insert it into DB resulting into
a failure. This patch fixes it.

Change-Id: I8b58750fa598e8d9a836114ecfecf11c7e84afd1
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-26 15:30:18.000000000', 'message': "WIP: [placement] Fix capacity tracking in POST /allocations

Add a change to _check_capacity_exceeded to also compare the amount
needed by a given allocation to a running total of amounts needed
against this class of resource on this resource provider.

WIP because this needs more tests and I'm too far down a rabbit hole
for my brain to be willing to do them. Suggestions welcome. Since we
didn't already have tests for this kind of thing, there's presumably a
bit of a blind spot that we need to fill in.

Change-Id: Id8dde9a1f4b62112925616dfa54e77704109481c
Closes-Bug: #1778743
